III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry.
Description (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care worker left youth unsupervised in vehicle in
temperatures below 30 degrees.
Investigation A telephone call was made to the Complainant on 12/14/2023 and
12/15/2023. There was no answer. A message was not left on the
telephone due to the complainant voicemail not being set up to
receive messages. An email message was sent to the
complainant on 12/19/23. To date there has been no
correspondence with the complainant to discuss his allegations
with the agency. In the allegation, it was reported that the agency
was found guilty of leaving two children unsupervised in a non-
running vehicle with temperatures in low 30’s freezing weather.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via video
conference on 12/19/2023. CA reported this was the first-time
hearing of this complaint against the agency. CA reported when
the allegation was discussed on 12/15/2023, the allegations was
discussed with the management team, and the management team
were unaware of the allegations prior to discussing the allegation
with this Consultant.
Foster Care Program Manager (FCPM) was interviewed via
video conference on 12/19/2023. FCPM reported the agency
does not usually provide transportation for the youths to or from
any of their parenting time visits. However due to unforeseen
circumstances the newly assigned foster care worker did transport
the youths on two occasions in November of 2023. She said it was
once on 11/3/2023 where the youth’s grandmother was in
attendance. This transport was due to the youth’s transporter car
being stolen. Another time was on 11/15/2023 following a
parenting time visit when the foster care worker offered to
transport the youths to their caregiver’s home to discuss and sign
a safety plan due to DHHS agency allegation. FCPM reported the
youth’s caregiver was with the worker and youths on 11/3/2023
during the transport. On 11/15/23 FCW transported the youths to
2

a private agency for a parenting time visit due to the caregiver not
having transportation. She reported at no time was the youths left
unattended or out in freezing cold weather.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed on 12/26/2023 via
telephone. FCW confirmed the information reported by FCPM.
She added at no time did she leave the youth unsupervised in a
vehicle in cold weather. She said on 11/3/2023, she transported
the youths to their caregiver home due to the transporter car being
stolen. On 11/15/2023, all individuals got out of the vehicle at the
same time and went inside of the caregiver’s home to discuss a
safety plan for the youths in the caregiver’s care. On both
occasions, the caregiver was in the car during the transport.
Caregiver was interviewed on 2/1/2024. The caregiver
confirmed that her car was stolen on 11/3/2023 and she could not
transport the youths in her care to their parenting time and that
she called the youths FCW for transportation. She reported FCW
picked her up from her home and transported her to the agency
for parenting time. She denied the youth were left unattended.
Caregiver confirmed being transported to another private agency
on 11/15/2023 by FCW with the youths in her care for parenting
time. She reported at no time were the youth left in a vehicle
unattended.
Foster Youth was interviewed on 2/1/2024. She verified being
transported to parenting time by FCW on two occasions. She
denied ever being left unattended.
Documentation Reviewed:
• DHHS complaint was reviewed regarding allegations of the
biological mother leaving one of her children in a vehicle
unattended.
• Foster Care Case File: It is noted that there are five
children involved with this case and the parents have
supervised parenting time visits weekly. Also noted, three
of the five youths are placed in a licensed/unlicensed
relative home. They were placed in this placement from
7/24/23 until 9/22/23 with a different agency. The foster
home placements and home were changed to the current
agency on 9/22/2023.
• Updated Service Plan dated 9/23/2023 – 12/21/2023 was
reviewed to confirm FCW provided transportation to
parenting visits.
3

• Safety Plan dated 11/15/2023 to show signatures of youth
and caregiver where the worker was in the home on this
date.
• Social Work Contact dated 11/22/23 where a parenting
time visit was held at another private agency where the
assigned FCW was in attendance.
Analysis It was reported that the assigned FCW did transport three youth
on 11/3/2023 and 11/15/2023 with the caregiver in attendance.
Both FCW and caregiver denied the youth were left unattended in
car at any point.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 (5) Development of service plans.
Section (5) An agency shall involve the child’s parent or parents and
Description the foster parents in the development of service plans to
enable the parent or parents and foster parents to understand
the plan for the child and the parents’ and the foster parents’
role in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan. An
agency shall give a copy to and review the parent agency
treatment plan with the parent and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster parent
that the information in the parent-agency treatment plan and
any other information about the child and the child’s family is
confidential.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency refused to involve parents with the youth treatment
plan.
Investigation Interview with the FCW on 01/30/2024 via telephone. She
reported the Complainant has not established legal paternity and
has requested that the FCW not contact him under any
circumstances.
Interview with Legal Guardian on 2/1/2024 via telephone. She
reported she would love to see and be more involved with her
children’s treatment plans. She said she has completed parenting
classes and has appropriate housing. She said she is waiting for
MDHHS to refer her for psychological/psychiatric evaluations.
She reported that now she is assigned an attorney, she will sign
any documents she needs to sign if it means bringing her children
home. She did not deny or confirm her involvement with
treatment plans.
4

DOCUMENTATION REVIEWED:
• SWC from 9/26/23 – 12/5/2023. The parents attended
twenty -two parenting time visits beginning from 9/29/2023
until 12/5/2023 on a weekly basis.
• Updated Service Plan dated 9/23/2023 – 12/21/2023. An
updated service plan was written by the agency dated
9/23/23 – 12/21/2023. The parent agency treatment plan
documented FCW attempted to deliver the PATP to the
mother on 1/3/2024 in person and again on 1/10/2024 by
mail delivery. FCW in her interview reported the mother
refused to sign the PATP when offered to her and refused
to return the PATP when it was mailed to her on 1/10/2024.
• FTM dated 12/19/2023. Documentation indicated that the
FCW held a FTM meeting on 12/19/2023, the biological
mother attended this meeting virtual with her attorney. She
provided input.
• Court hearing held on 1/22/2024 stated MDHHS shall
continue to host FTM every two weeks and invite all
counsel to attend. Mother shall be referred for
psychological and psychiatric evaluations at MDHHS
expense. Four of the mother’s children are to be referred
for individual therapy.
Analysis Based on documentation, the biological mother was provided the
opportunity to participate in the youth treatment plan. It was
documented by FCW the biological mother refused to participate
in the youth treatment plan and did not accept the treatment plan
per delivery in person or mailing. However, the biological mother
attended parenting time weekly and was involved providing
feedback in a FTM dated 12/19/2023.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISH
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: The report investigated two allegations against Hands Across the Water: that a foster care worker left youth unsupervised in a cold vehicle, and that the agency refused to involve parents in treatment plans. The investigation found no evidence to support the vehicle allegation, as interviews and documentation confirmed a caregiver was present during all transports. Regarding parent involvement, documentation showed the biological mother was offered the treatment plan but refused to sign it, though she did attend meetings and parenting time. The investigation concluded no violations were established for either allegation, effectively clearing the agency of culpability.
